message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of sinusitis and nasal drainage, along with fatigue and joint pain, which are common symptoms of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA). Additionally, there is inflammation and bleeding of the nasal mucosa and tenderness over the maxillary sinuses. The presence of hematuria and proteinuria suggests renal involvement, which is common in GPA. Churg-Strauss syndrome and Sarcoidosis do not typically present with these symptoms, and although Immunoglobulin A nephropathy can cause hematuria and proteinuria, it is not associated with the other symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of sinusitis and nasal drainage with purulent and occasionally hemorrhagic drainage, along with joint pain and inflammation of the nasal mucosa. These symptoms suggest the most likely diagnosis is Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), which is often characterized by sinusitis and kidney problems. The microscopic hematuria and proteinuria results indicate kidney damage, which is also commonly seen in GPA. The other options are less likely as they do not present with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The chronic sinusitis, joint pain, and renal involvement suggest a systemic disease. The purulent and hemorrhagic nasal drainage and inflammation of the nasal mucosa suggest granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis). The other options do not fit the symptoms and signs as well.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of sinusitis, nasal drainage, hematuria, and proteinuria suggest a diagnosis of Granulomatosis with polyangiitis. Other options, such as Sarcoidosis, have granulomatous inflammation but typically do not present with hematuria or proteinuria. Churg-Strauss syndrome can present with sinusitis and joint pain, but it is rare and presents with marked eosinophilia, which is not mentioned in the scenario. Immunoglobulin A nephropathy typically presents with asymptomatic hematuria and proteinuria without systemic symptoms like sinusitis and joint pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, also known as Wegener’s granulomatosis. This condition is characterized by inflammation of the blood vessels, leading to organ damage and various clinical manifestations including sinusitis, joint pain, and renal involvement. The presence of hematuria and proteinuria is also consistent with renal involvement in the disease. Churg-Strauss syndrome is a type of vasculitis that affects small and medium-sized blood vessels, but is typically associated with asthma and eosinophilia. Immunoglobulin A nephropathy is a form of kidney disease that typically presents with hematuria and proteinuria, but is not associated with sinusitis or joint pain. Sarcoidosis is a multisystem disease characterized by the formation of granulomas, but is typically not associated with sinusitis or joint pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) - a multisystem autoimmune disease that affects small- and medium-sized blood vessels. The sinusitis and nasal drainage with purulent and occasionally hemorrhagic discharge suggest upper respiratory tract involvement. Joint pain and fatigue suggest systemic involvement. Microscopic hematuria and proteinuria suggest kidney involvement. Churg-Strauss syndrome is another possible diagnosis for the same presentation, but it is characterized by peripheral eosinophilia, which is not mentioned in the patient’s history. Immunoglobulin A nephropathy and sarcoidosis are not commonly associated with sinusitis and joint pain.

The patient presents with symptoms of chronic sinusitis and nasal drainage, along with fatigue and joint pain, which are suggestive of Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis. The presence of hematuria and proteinuria suggest kidney involvement, which is common in this disease. Churg-Strauss Syndrome and Sarcoidosis can also have similar symptoms but they are less likely to involve the kidneys. Immunoglobulin A Nephropathy is primarily a kidney disease and does not present with sinusitis and joint pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of chronic sinusitis, joint pains, and hematuria and proteinuria, suggesting the most likely diagnosis is granulomatosis with polyangiitis. Churg-Strauss syndrome and Sarcoidosis may also have similar symptoms, but they are less commonly associated with hematuria and proteinuria. Immunoglobulin A nephropathy usually does not have nasal and joint symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is showing symptoms of both sinusitis and joint pain, suggesting a systemic disease. The purulent and hemorrhagic nasal drainage, along with hematuria and proteinuria, suggests a vasculitis. Among the options, granulomatosis with polyangiitis is the most likely diagnosis.

The purulent and occasionally hemorrhagic nasal drainage, along with joint pain and inflammation, suggests the most likely diagnosis is Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (previously known as Wegener's granulomatosis). The hematuria and proteinuria may indicate renal involvement commonly seen in this disease. Churg-Strauss syndrome is also a possible diagnosis but it typically presents with asthma and peripheral eosinophilia. Immunoglobulin A nephropathy and Sarcoidosis don't usually present with nasal symptoms and joint pain.
